page.title: 05MARTIN MILL VILLAGE
page.content: Martin Mill owes its existence to the railway station. It grew up after 1881 whereas the parent village of Martin is at least 1000 years older. The station now provides a good service along the London to Sandwich line. At peak times the trains call there every 30 minutes. There are 57 houses in the village more than half_post war. There is a public house;"The Ugly Duckling", and a farm shop which is part of the Hawthorn Caravan and Camping site. Once a farm,it's 25 acres to the south of the village have been laid out to cater for 153 static homes many occupied by retired people in the summer. This contrasts with rest of the village where only 14% are retired folk. The station has made the village a dormitory but 2 out of 3 people use cars to get to work,school and shops,chiefly in Dover.
